text: welcome to black hat windows security conference 2002 held february 7th through the 9th in new orleans louisiana
the following video tape was reported live at the conference and produced by the sound of knowledge incorporated
i'm eric schultz i'm from microsoft i'm part of the security strategies team i've spent the last
year to year and a half of my life trying to make this patch madness easier for customers and
for ourselves so i want to step you through some things that we've been doing over the past year year
and a half some things that we're rolling out over the next few months to uh to help all customers out with patch
management issues so we're going to talk about some tools some processes methodologies schemas and so forth feel
free to ask questions along the way and we'll dive right in
so we hope to address the following questions today how do we know if our enterprise is up to date on patches
how many folks today can feel comfortable that your entire enterprise is up to date on patches client-side
stuff server stuff it's it's a scary proposition and
up until a few months ago there were really no tools available to do that especially for server side things before
windows upstate update started carrying iis and so forth so i want to cover some tools to show that
how do we know when a new patch has been released when was the last time that microsoft released a security patch
today today yes today we release a security patch so how do you know how can you be
alerted to these things how do we know the patch is still valid on the system how many times have you
installed something yet the files were later overwritten by something else and you don't know if that patch is still
valid on your system maybe you installed iis patches you went back and then you reinstalled your web
server did you overwrite the patches or not well we'll show you how you can tell
how can i deploy patches to all of these machines short of walking around to each one individually and executing it and
what is microsoft planning to do to make it easier to get these patches deployed going forward and to do the assessments
and the validation so we're going to talk about the process how do we understand what's available
how do we scan the network to see what needs it how do we deploy these patches and how do we validate that they're still on the
system first step in this process if you're not
already signed up sign up for the security bulletin notification service at microsoft's you can take down this
url i'll also make the slides available on blackhat.com website so you can pull down the slideshow later
um subscribe to the security bullet bullet notification service and you'll get an email with a couple paragraphs telling
you that there's a new bulletin available you can read on the microsoft website that's a must
windows update will automatically tell you the new patch is available to be downloaded for your system
windows update lags the actual release of the patch from anywhere from
a couple hours to a couple weeks potentially depending where in the cycle the windows
update is so if you want to get the instant notification then keep subscribe to the bulletin notification service
has anyone tried the client update notification applet i haven't used it myself it's um it's a

it's part of the stpp cd-rom that microsoft shipped but again i can't

deploy people really liked the hf check idea so
we want to extend it to include the operating system internet explorer sql server and we'll be extending this to

and

check what all the different switches do the domain switches network switches
um suppressing certain messages output files you want to have tab delimited

read the queue article and it's all it's all explained in that
so how does hf net check work the first thing it does is it has to obtain the data file to know what
hotfixes are available for what platforms so the tool will usually go out to the internet to the microsoft.com
site and it will download a copy of of the ms secure.xml file
it's about a meg in size so to make it a quicker download we can press it into a cab file and when it's in a cab file
format we can also digitally sign it so you know it's coming from microsoft because the last thing i'd like to have
happen is for someone to hijack your dns point it to some evil site and have you
download some evil cab file or some evil xml file that tells you that your box is up to date when it's really not so we
sign everything and hf netcheck will check the signature and if it's properly signed by microsoft it'll expand it and
use it if it's not signed by microsoft it'll pop up warnings and tell you
now if you happen to be working on a disconnected system you can download this file from one of your internet
systems put it on a floppy disk carry it over to your disconnected system load up the file and you can actually use a
local copy of the xml file it'll then check the tool hfnetcheck will check itself to see whether or not
it's running the latest version of hfnetcheck so in the xml file that comes down to your box we put on what the
latest version of hf net check should be and if you're not running the latest version we'll give you a little message
it'll say a new version of the tools available please go and download it you can continue to use the old version
of the tool if you like or you can go grab a new one once it's done that it'll go out into all the machines that
you've got it'll identify the language of the operating system that you're running the operating system level service pack
level and what versions of ie sql and iis and so forth that you're running
it'll then go into the xml file and it'll identify all the hotfixes that are available for those particular operating
system service packs platforms because you don't want a patch that's applicable to windows 2000 gold if you're running
windows 2000 sp2 you only want to see the sp2 patches
what's really nice too is that if we released a security roll-up hotfix it includes all the post sp2
hotfixes so there might be 17 post sp2 hotfixes you don't need to apply all 17
you only need to apply the one hotfix so the xml file maintains information about supersedences and which bulletins
supersede which other bulletins and patches so we'll only show you what's necessary to be applied to be current
so we see in this case i've got a this little tool i use to manage the xml file i've got bulletin 01-048
in this case it's applicable to windows nt workstation servers
nt service pack 6a so you're only going to see this if you're running 6a and you can see the sq number 305 3999 so you
know the queue number it goes to i have a little summary information in there about what the bulletin says
we'll talk about some new features we're putting into this shortly so for each hotfix
we're going to go in and look in your system's registry to see whether or not you have the registry key that correlates with having installed this
hotfix if we don't see the registry key on your system then
we'll assume the hotfix has not been applied and we'll kick out a message and says patch not applied
if we do see the hotfix applied we'll go on to the next uh the next check now how many folks
roll their own hot fixes i know microsoft does sometimes other folks do so you may not write registry
keys so you don't want to receive false positives so you can use the dash z switch which will disable the registry
keys all together we won't even check registry keys we'll go straight to the next step
which is file checks um
let's see so if the key does exist or if you've ignored the key
then we're going to go and we're going to check the file version of every file in that patch and the check sum of all
those files to make sure that what we shipped in the patch is actually what is installed on your system
so in this case we've got three files in this particular patch and we can see the file versions over on the right hand
side we can see the check sums it expects to see the path on the system of where we would expect to find this
particular file and the file date and so forth so a lot
of good file details in here if if either the file version or the checksum are not correct then we're going to
throw up a warning message or a patch not found message to tell you that there might be a missing patch on this system
there might be a case where an attacker has modified or put a trojan version of one of these files on your system
in which case they may not get the file version right they may not get the checksum right so we're going to flag that and tell you
or they might make the file version really really new in which case we're going to throw up a warning message and
say hey the file version this is newer than what we expect you might want to go check it out because something might be
wrong with it so if anything doesn't match we'll throw
up warnings or patch not installed messages but when you run hf net check and it's going to verify if a patch has
been applied or not it's always going to go check file versions and check sums and we're going to check some additional
things in some future versions as well so this is one way you can use to validate your if you've applied a patch
or not moving forward we're going to extend the xml file and the hotfix checking to
support more than just english language patches we're going to actually include patch details for all languages
we're going to have download urls for each specific patch for each language
so you can third-party developers can write tools to parse the xml file and
you can pull out the specific download patch and you can automatically go and download the patch from microsoft if you choose to do that so all this data will
be available we're going to record the hotfix installer engine does it use the
update.exe hotfix.exe is it an internet explorer hotfix installer what switches are available
for quiet mode no reboot mode all the different modes of installer engines will record for every
patch so you can programmatically determine what you might want to do to auto install the patch
we're going to record the md5 and sha-1 hashes for all these files so it's going
to make it tougher for people to try to fool the system so that we can then compare using any of
these file versions the file hash values specific file locations where would we
expect to find the file on the box if you're running multiple versions of sql server and you've created virtual routes
we can peer in the registry to determine where the file should be and report on it if you've got multi-proc versus
single proc boxes we have different files we're going to record those pieces 32-bit versus 64-bit systems you can
check severity data we've included severity data on security bulletins for every patch we'll include that in the xml file
and give you some switches so you can only view the most severe issues or all the issues
we'll include links to cve data so you can then cross-reference it back
to other vulnerability databases and we'll also record what types of reboot actions might be required after you've
applied the patch so we a lot of cool data that we record about every single fix that we do all this plus all the
file specifics file versions some summary bulletin data in the xml file that's on the microsoft website freely
available you can bring it down parse it yourself you can write third-party tools or leverage third-party tools that will
read this xml file and go from there i also like to encourage that there's other vendors that are interested in
doing a similar thing let's see the rest of the world also adopts similar methods to help patch our systems

corporate version of windows update is another tool that we're coming out with should be releasing shortly this
allows you to take the microsoft windows update service and bring it into your own organization so you can run your own

out your firewall via port 80 up to the microsoft windows update server will download
